en_results_raw: she was so limp, and I just knew something was wrong. I tried to wake her up, but she wouldn't respond. I was in a panic, my heart racing, and I didn't know what to do. I called my husband, and he told me to call 911. I was trying to stay calm, but I was freaking out inside. The operator answered, and I tried to explain what was happening, but I could barely get the words out. She kept telling me to stay on the line and that help was on the way. It felt like an eternity before the paramedics arrived. They rushed in, and I could see the concern on their faces. They took her from me and started working on her. I was in a daze, watching, but not really seeing. My mind was racing with worst-case scenarios. The next thing I knew, they were rushing her out the door, and I was left standing there, feeling helpless and scared. The wait at the hospital was agonizing. I was pacing back and forth, trying to get someone to tell me something, anything. Finally, a doctor came out, and his expression was grim. He told me that she had stopped breathing for a few minutes, and they were doing everything they could to save her. I felt like my world had come crashing down around me. I couldn't lose her, not now, not ever. I prayed, I begged, I pleaded with whatever higher power was out there to please, please bring my baby back to me. The hours ticked by, and I was a mess, but I refused to give up hope. And then, finally, after what felt like an eternity, the doctor came out again, and this time, he was smiling. He told me that she was going to be okay, that she had pulled through. I collapsed to the floor, relief washing over me like a wave. I knew that I would never take a single moment with her for granted again. She was my miracle, my fighter, and I would do anything to keep her safe.

She just keeps watching, her face expressionless, as I stand there, frozen, with my hand still touching the baby's face.
